sen.j: 正徳 (日本)5年（1716年）8月5日 (旧暦)、万役山事件について徳山藩主･毛利元次に諫言するも聞き入れられずに家名断絶･追放され、三田尻向島（現在の防府市）に閉居した。
sen.e: On August 5, 1716 (old calendar), Satondo remonstrated with Mototsugu MORI, the lord of Tokuyama domain, about the Manyakuyama incident, but was not taken heed, and he was forced to forfeit the family name and was also exiled, so he confined himself in Mitajiri Mukaijima (present-day Hofu City).

sen.j: 翌年の徳山藩改易の報に驚き、直ちに徳山に伺候し百次郎（後の毛利元尭）に謁した。
sen.e: The next year, the news that the Tokuyama domain forfeited their fief surprised Satondo, and he immediately presented himself in Tokuyama and had an audience with Hyakujiro (the later Mototaka MORI)

sen.e: Rather, for this reason, Satondo was promoted in the Hagi Domain and the domain tried to entrust Satondo to deal with the aftermath of the forfeit even inviting him to become an officer, but Satondo cleverly steered the conversation away from this topic.

sen.e: Instead Satondo studied calligraphy under Shorenin-no-miya in Kyoto, in which he had studied under before, using the excuse that he also wanted medical treatment for his chronic disease he applied to be issued a passport.

sen.j: 里人は京都を拠点として、江戸･大坂･徳山市･萩市など各地に散らばった仲間と連絡を取り合い、情報を集めながら時期を待ち、享保4年1月 (旧暦)（1719年）、里人は「周防徳山領百姓中」と署名し、嘆願書を老中･水野忠之、大目付･横田重松、目付･千葉七郎右衛門の3人宛てに投書した。
sen.e: Satondo used Kyoto as a foothold, and contacted his comrades spread through out various places such as Edo, Osaka, Tokuyama City, Hagi City, and gathered information; while gathering information he waited, and in January 1719 (old calendar), Satondo wrote a petition addressed to Senior Councilor Tadayuki MIZUNO, Ometsuke (chief inspector of the Edo shogunate) Shigematsu Yokoda, and Metsuke (inspector of foot soldiers) Shichirouemon CHIBA, signed by the "Suo Tokuyama Region Peasants."

sen.e: This petition won the sympathy of the cabinet officials of the Shogunate, and with a comment that the forfeit of the fief was too harsh of a punishment, restoration of the Tokuyama domain was decided.

sen.e: After the restoration took the shape that Yoshimoto asked for on May 28 (old calendar), Mototsugu was released from custody, and just as Yoshimoto asked for before, Mototsugu's withdraw and Hyakujiro's succession to the family headship was permitted.
